utterances: Yeah.
And it was towards the end of that project and they came to me with this instrumental track and they just said, you know, this seems like your vibe.
Let's see if you can write something.
And I just - I don't know, it just immediately put me at ease and I just felt captured.
(Soundbite of song ""Closer"")

The feeling of starting to complete something, getting ready to put it out into the world and I had excitement and fear and all of those feelings about it, and ended up just going into Amp Live's home studio at the time and just recording whatever came to my mind.
And it was just going to be a scratch thing, you know, just for an idea, but the vibe was there so we just kept it.
(Soundbite of song ""Closer"")
(Singing) I'm going higher closer to my dreams.
I'm going higher and higher.
I can almost reach.
Some times you just have to let it go.
You have a background in activism.
You have some roots in South Africa as well as here in the U.S.
What are you going to pass on to your new baby about who you are, who the grandparents that your baby will love are and all of that?
What a good question.
That's what I'm figuring out.
And that's what I'll be figuring out for her whole life and my whole life.
You know how to pass on what I think is important - about the importance of family and community.

How I started my musical career, officially, was really like my family and I deciding to put out, you know, the ""Closer"" album that started really small, you know, with a vision that we'd make it pass there.
And I think having that family support and knowing that we can lean on each other has allowed it to grow, you know.
And we started Skyblaze recordings and got distribution and it has been able to grow and allowed me to put out the music that I believe in.
So I hope that she grows up knowing the importance of family and family support, and knowing that whatever she does there's room for it, you know, if she really believes in it.
That's beautiful.
Yeah.
Goapele, thank you so much for coming in.
Thank you.
(Soundbite of music)
Soul singer Goapele.
Her latest disc is called ""Change It All."" She joined me in our NPR West studios.
From the studios of NPR West, this is Day to Day.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
And I'm Alex Cohen.
Here in California, the winds have shifted and many of the wildfires are finally getting under control.
We'll take stock of the damage later in the show.
First, politics.
Oh, New Hampshire, you queen of primary states, when will you stop primping and come on down for the party?
New Hampshire has still not set a date for its presidential primary, traditionally the first in the nation.
Other states have crowded earlier and earlier, especially Michigan, with primaries on January 15th.

And it's looking likely that Iowa will hold its caucuses for both Democrats and Republicans on January 3rd, and that means New Hampshire could go the following Tuesday, January 8th and still have a whole week before Michigan votes.
But New Hampshire is still not ready to say what it will do.
Bill Gardner is secretary of State in New Hampshire.
He's held that job for 31 years.
He is the person who sets the date.
Bill Gardner, welcome to Day to Day.
And why the delay this year?
Well, I have actually waited until the 20th of December to set the date.
And some years it can be done in September or October.

What's different this time is that there are so many states having primaries or caucuses earlier, and so we're getting closer to the time when it's going to begin, and that's earlier than ever before.
So when do you plan to announce the day?

Well, it wouldn't be before the end of the filing period, the time that candidates fill out the declaration of candidacy forms, and that will end a week from today, November 2nd, and it will be some time after that.
But just when after that, I don't know.

The biggest paper in your state - the Manchester Union Leader - has a political story today saying that Michigan, which has been, I think, most critical of New Hampshire's leading role in this, it looks as though Michigan is going to have their primary on January 15th, which means you could pick January 8th; that would work for you.
Well, I'm still pretty cautious about that.
You don't trust Michigan?
There's been so many twists and turns during this process this time that I have reason to be cautious.
So you hired a blue ribbon panel of experts to come in and judge, right?
Now, a new cookbook promises to take the ache out of baking.

Nancy Baggett is the author of ""Kneadlessly, that's K-N-E-A-D - Kneadlessly Simple: Fabulous, Fuss-Free, No-Knead Breads."" She lives and bakes in Ellicott City, Maryland, not far from Washington, D.C., so we paid a visit to her kitchen to learn the secrets of kneadless baking.
Kneadless bread, in fact - we think of it as very novel and revolutionary now â€” kneadless bread is actually the way it was made before people figured out that you could knead bread.
There's a chemical process that goes on.
It bubbles, and that natural bubbling action of the yeast, actually if you give it time, it will knead itself.
What kind of bread are we going to make?
We're going to make your classic, crusty, artisan-style pot bowl(ph).
I call it a pot bowl because you make it in a pot, and it actually provides the steam that gives you that crustiness that you would otherwise have to have a commercial, steam-jetted oven to make.
It is my version of the very famous New York Times recipe.
There have been multiple versions, and I've heard that mine's the best, she says modestly.
(Soundbite of laughter)
So let me go ahead and get started.
It does - as I say, it does have its own little method that's a little different.
The first thing I probably should mention is the method in which I tell you to measure the flour.
You scoop down into either the sack or canister and scrape across the top, and it takes four cups.
And you're just putting it into a nice, big, clear, glass mixing bowl.
Into a big bowl.
And the big bowl is really important because this takes a long, slow rise, it will really, really puff up.
And so, even though you might be used to a bread that rises, maybe doubles, it will, say, double in bulk, this is likely to go up three times.
So if you skimp on the bowl, you may have, whoa, dough coming out at the top.
Baggett adds the ingredients with the quick, precise movements all professional chefs seem to have.
The flour, rapid-rising yeast, a touch of salt, sugar for extra flavor and one key component, ice-cold water.

And the reason that we use the ice-cold water is it gives, it's called retarded first fermentation, a fancy way of saying the yeast is retarded by the cold water, and enzymes then go to work, giving the bread extra good flavor and texture.
Now, simply stir this together.
It takes a little bit of elbow grease, but in about 30 seconds, it'll be blended together, scraping down the sides just a little bit.
And that, after you scrape it down, is it.
Nancy Baggett gives her dough a quick squirt of cooking spray, covers it in plastic wrap and sets it aside.
Now, if you were baking this at home, you'd have to set your dough aside for 12 hours or so, then stir it a little bit and let it rise for a few hours more.
So through the magic of radio, we happen to have, right here, a risen blob of dough, ready to be popped into the oven.
Baggett pulls out a pot, a Dutch oven, any Dutch oven, that's been preheating, and she tests it to be sure that it's warm enough before tipping in the dough.
The way you know that it's ready.
(Soundbite of sizzling)
Is if you sprinkle a little water, it should steam.
